c7en00985b_fig1.jpg.title: Interaction of titanium dioxide nanoparticles with soil components and plants: current knowledge and future research needs – a critical review  - Environmental Science: Nano (RSC Publishing) DOI:10.1039/C7EN00985B
c7en00985b_fig1.jpg.full_caption: Schematic representation of uses and dispersion in the environment of nano-TiO2 and interaction with the plants. The percentage of nano-TiO2 released into water, soil, and landfill were calculated based on the data given by Keller et al.1

c7en00985b_fig2.jpg.title: Interaction of titanium dioxide nanoparticles with soil components and plants: current knowledge and future research needs – a critical review  - Environmental Science: Nano (RSC Publishing) DOI:10.1039/C7EN00985B
c7en00985b_fig2.jpg.full_caption: Results of the interaction of nano-TiO2 with plants (A) TEM images of wheat root tips exposed to 90 mg kg−1 nano-TiO2 (modified from Du et al.);22 (B) μ-XRF images of lettuce stems grown with 1000 mg kg−1 nano-TiO2 (modified from Larue et al., 2016);25 (C) μ-XRF and μ-XANES images of cucumber leaves from plants exposed to 4000 mg kg−1 nano-TiO2 (modified from Servin et al.23); (D) μ-XRF and μ-XANES images of cucumber fruits from exposed to 750 mg kg−1 nano-TiO2 (modified from Servin et al.26); (E) representation of photosynthesis parameters possibly altered by nano-TiO2 in chloroplasts; (F) loading plot of PLS-DA of metabolic analysis of rice leaves from plants exposed to 500 mg kg−1 nano-TiO2 (modified from Wu et al.31); (G) optical microscopy image of onion roots exposed to 100 mg kg−1 nano-TiO2 (modified from Pakrashi et al.32). Red, green, and blue color in (B)–(D) represents titanium, potassium, and calcium, respectively.

c7en00985b_fig3.jpg.title: Interaction of titanium dioxide nanoparticles with soil components and plants: current knowledge and future research needs – a critical review  - Environmental Science: Nano (RSC Publishing) DOI:10.1039/C7EN00985B
c7en00985b_fig3.jpg.full_caption: Schematic summary of the interactions between soil and nano-TiO2. (A) Parameters in orange boxes are the factors of soil affecting behaviors of nano-TiO2 (in blue circles); (B) effects of nano-TiO2 on soil properties. Abbreviations: EC, electricity conductivity; TOD, total oxygen demand; TSS, total suspended solids.

c7en00985b_fig4.jpg.title: Interaction of titanium dioxide nanoparticles with soil components and plants: current knowledge and future research needs – a critical review  - Environmental Science: Nano (RSC Publishing) DOI:10.1039/C7EN00985B
c7en00985b_fig4.jpg.full_caption: Interaction of NOM with nano-TiO2 of different crystal phase and surface properties: (A) soil colloids coated with negatively charged and hydrophilic (red circle) natural organic matters, (B) positively charged nano-TiO2 with a hydrophilic coating, (C) negatively charged nano-TiO2 with a hydrophilic coating, (D) negatively charged plain anatase (yellow dot) nano-TiO2, (E) negatively charged plain rutile (pink dot) nano-TiO2, (F) negatively charged nano-TiO2 with a hydrophobic (blue circle) coating, (G) positively charged nano-TiO2 with a hydrophobic coating.

c7en00985b_fig5.jpg.title: Interaction of titanium dioxide nanoparticles with soil components and plants: current knowledge and future research needs – a critical review  - Environmental Science: Nano (RSC Publishing) DOI:10.1039/C7EN00985B
c7en00985b_fig5.jpg.full_caption: Summary of detection methods used to study the interaction between nano-TiO2 and plants (abbreviations: μ-XANES, micro X-ray absorption spectroscopic near edge structure; μ-XRF, micro X-ray fluorescence; CM, confocal microscopy; EM, electron microscopy; FM, fluorescence microscopy; FT-IR, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy; GC-MS, gas chromatography-mass spectrometry; GC-ToF-MS, gas chromatography-time-of-flight-mass spectrometry; 1H NMR, proton nuclear magnetic resonance; ICP-OES/MS, inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry/mass spectrometry; OM, optical microscopy; UV/vis, ultraviolet/visible spectroscopy).

c7en00985b_fig6.jpg.title: Interaction of titanium dioxide nanoparticles with soil components and plants: current knowledge and future research needs – a critical review  - Environmental Science: Nano (RSC Publishing) DOI:10.1039/C7EN00985B
c7en00985b_fig6.jpg.full_caption: Trend of studies in the interaction between nano-TiO2 and plant systems. Blue box summarized the major findings in the study of each growth stage (orange box).
